awd_titl_txt: Laboratory and Numerical Experiments on Ocean-scale Turbulent Stratified Mixing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use laboratory experiments and numerical modelling techniques to identify the mechanism by which waters in the surface of the ocean are mixed with heavier deeper waters through a process that is called overturning. Water in the world oceans is arranged in nearly-horizontal layers of density increasing with depth. Because of the difference in density, transfer of material between layers (i.e., lifting of denser water and sinking of lighter water) requires an external source of energy and the whole process is called mixing. There is considerable interest in understanding mixing in stratified bodies of water. This process is slow; it is estimated that it takes about 1,000 years to completely overturn the ocean. Yet, since the deep ocean holds large stores of heat and carbon dioxide, the overturning process is important as it regulates climate on the planet over millennial and longer time scales, and thus of great societal interest.

Stratified mixing requires a source of energy (stirring), and the aim of this project is to characterize the efficiency of the process. To understand the concept of efficiency, it is convenient to think by analogy to an automobile. The gas burned in the engine releases a certain amount of energy, but only a fraction of it goes into moving the drivetrain. The rest is lost as heat. Likewise, only a fraction of the energy provided by the stirring mechanism goes into doing work against gravity, the rest being dissipated as frictional heat. Direct observations of ocean mixing with increasingly high resolution using, for example, acoustic sensors and fast temperature sensors, have shown surprising structures in shear-driven turbulence that suggest mixing at ocean scales may behave differently than small-scale laboratory measurements have suggested. This project addresses these issues through the study of turbulent mixing in carefully controlled laboratory experiments at scales relevant to oceanic flows and the use of numerical simulations. The experimental component is conducted in the UNC Joint Fluid Lab tank, a 36m long facility in which stratified shear flows with high buoyancy Reynolds number can be generated. This ensures a clear separation between the Kolmogorov and Ozmidov scales. The experiments are designed to establish the behavior of the flux Richardson number (a measure of efficiency), in the limit of high buoyancy Reynolds number and finite gradient Richardson number. The data acquired in the lab are used to train, via data-assimilation, a suite of increasingly complex numerical models, with the final goal of creating tools that can be used to diagnose efficiency from ocean data and to improve the parameterization of stratified mixing in global models.

por.por_cntn:
Internal waves in the world oceans, though hardly discernible from the surface, play a mojor role in promoting the transport of heat, gases and other properties across surfaces of constant density. This is because when the internal waves overturn (akin to whitecapping surface waves), vigorous mixing esues. In view of this property, internal waves play a major role in regulating the exchange of greenhouses gases and heat between the surface and the deep ocean. 

Conducting observations of internal waves in the open ocean is a time- and labor-intensive endeavour. Moreover, measurements are confined to lines (mostly vertical), which makes it difficult to characterize the process in its entirety. 

For modeling and long-term forecasting applications, the quantity that most matter is the rate of exchange of heat and gases across surfaces of constant density. However, in practice it is easier to measure the rate at which turbulent fluctuations dissipate kinetic energy. The latter measurement is then used to estimate the heat and tracer fluxes. 

How the two quantities relate has been the subject of a vigorous debate. In this project, we used experiments to address this question. In tanks of various size, we setup a stratified fluid, with the density decreasing from the the bottom towards the surface. Internal waves are generated towing an obstacle back and forth, mimicking the effect of tidal currents over submarine topography. Under appropriate paratmers, this motion generates internal waves which propagate in the tank. 

With a combination of optical and in-situ measurement techniques, we can get a fairly detailed quantitaive picture of the internal wave field in the tank, and also obtain detailed measurements of velocity, shear and energy dissipation, in a way that would be impossible in the ocean. We can also measure the forces acting on the fluid, and thus the rate at which energy is injected by the wave-maker. 

Just as in the ocean, energy enters the system in a narrow frequency band. Wave breaking and overturning occurs at much smaller frequencies. In the ocean, a continuum of frequencies laying in-between the injection and dissipation energy is energized. Our goal was to emulate this behavior in the experiments.

We can broadly define the experiments conduicted in two categories: If the tank is "small", (smallness being quantified by an appropriate non dimensional parameter), frictional effects remove energy from the internal wave field very efficiently, and energy spreads from the forcing frequency only to two other frequencies, a process that was theoretically predicted and is called a Resonant Triad Interaction.. However, in our largest tank, which measures 9mx3mx1m, we saw the development of several peaks in the energy-vs.-frequency plot, indicating that nonlinear effects become dominant over purely viscous effects.   

This research shows that it is possible to reproduce in a laboratory setting features of the real ocean, but it requires large facilities.
